The event organizers cleverly set it up in the small park directly behind the architectural landmark, which offered a more relaxed atmosphere than a formal conference room. While there was a bit of initial awkwardness as everyone pitched their ‘elevator speech’, I found people were genuinely interested in hearing about my work with medicinal herbs and natural remedies. My biggest tip would be to prepare a concise and engaging introduction, and focus on genuinely connecting with individuals rather than simply collecting business cards, and it was a good experience.

pos_document: 2024-1-7 16:14, Sebastian: I believe a key aspect is maintaining a friendly and open demeanor, which I found particularly useful during a speed networking event I attended recently near Dizzie Showteater. As someone who spends a lot of time observing interactions in the rainforest – though usually with macaws rather than marketing professionals – I was initially apprehensive about the fast-paced format, but it was surprisingly effective. I managed to exchange contact information with several people genuinely interested in wildlife photography and conservation, potentially leading to some exciting collaborations. My tip would be to have a concise “elevator pitch” prepared, highlighting what you do and what you’re hoping to gain from the event, because the time really does fly by. Ultimately, it wasn’t awkward at all, and I left feeling optimistic about the potential connections made at Dizzie Showteater – though I definitely preferred the sounds of the rainforest!
